Name: Jar
Description: Buff-coloured pottery vessel with rounded base, small looped handles for suspension cords, wide mouth with pronounced rim, and red-painted decoration comprising simple daubs of colour. The form is typical of mid- to late fourth millennium BC richer burials in Upper Egypt. This vessel was excavated at the key early settlement near Kom el-Ahmar (the Hierakonpolis of later texts) in southern Upper Egypt. The grave goods date the burial to the second half of the fourth millennium, when the culture of Upper Egypt was expanding northwards over Lower Egypt.
